label: Review
abstract: Endophytic fungi comprise host-associated fungal communities which thrive within the tissues of host plants and produce a diverse range of secondary metabolites with various bioactive attributes. The metabolites such as phenols, polyketides, saponins, alkaloids help to mitigate biotic and abiotic stresses, fight against pathogen attacks and enhance the plant immune system. We present an overview of the association of endophytic fungal communities with a plant host and discuss molecular mechanisms induced during their symbiotic interaction. The overview focuses on the secondary metabolites (especially those of terpenoid nature) secreted by endophytic fungi and their respective function. The recent advancement in multi-omics approaches paved the way for identification of these metabolites and their characterization via comparative analysis of extensive omics datasets. This study also elaborates on the role of diverse endophytic fungi associated with key agricultural crops and hence important for sustainability of agriculture.

abstract: The potential use of microorganisms as biotechnological sources of industrially important enzymes has stimulated interest in exploration of extracellular enzymatic activity in several microorganisms. Endophytic fungi are those fungi which colonize plants internally without apparent adverse effect. Endophytic fungi are relatively unexplored producers of metabolites useful to pharmaceutical and agricultural industries. As a result, the role of endophytes in production of various natural products with greater bioactivity has received increased attention. Endophytic fungi have been found to degrade lignocellulose consisting of lignin, cellulose and hemicellulose with the aid of lignocellulases enzynes. This review highlights the potential of endophytic fungi for production of lignocellulases and also discusses the present status and future prospectives in this field.

abstract: The bark of Syzygium cumini is potential as an antimicrobial agent, so this bark is a reservoir of endophytic fungi. The purpose of this study was to isolate endophytic fungi and determine its antifungal activity. Several methods used in this research are surface sterilization, endophytic isolation on plain media and media containing host plant, morphology identification of endophytic fungi and determine antifungal activity. Thirteen endophytic fungi have been isolated from the bark of S. cumini, in which seven and six endophytic fungi grow on the plain media and media containing host plants, respectively. Based on the morphology identification, these endophytic fungi include the genus Phomopsis, Colletotrichum and Aspergillus. Seven endophytic fungi displayed antifungal activity against pathogenic microorganisms. The results demonstrated that endophytic fungi isolate from S. cumini bark could be a source of antifungal agents.

abstract: This study aimed at investigating the diversity of endophytic fungi from Coptis chinensis and their activity against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Seventy-nine fungal isolates obtained from C. chinensis were identified to belong to 27 species based on morphological features and internal transcript spacer (ITS) gene sequencing analysis. Comparing relative frequency values, the most frequent genera were Colletotrichum and Fusarium, while most frequent species were C. gloeosporioides and F. avenaceum. Analysis of diversity indices indicated that C. chinensis harbored abundant fungal resources. Methanol extracts of fungal endophyte cultures were evaluated for antibacterial activity against S. aureus ATCC 25923 and two other MRSA clinical strains. Nine of 27 endophytic fungi exhibited inhibitory activities against S. aureus ATCC 25923. Among them, Paraboeremia litseae HL-17, Fusarium sp. HL-23, and Fusarium sp. HL-27 exhibited obvious inhibition against the three S. aureus strains. Our findings suggest that the endophytic fungi in C. chinensis have a high diversity and an obvious tissue specificity, and could be of potential interest in screening anti-MRSA agents. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report on the diversity and anti-MRSA activity of fungal endophytes from C. chinensis.

abstract: Dipsacus asperoides contains multiple pharmacologically active compounds. The principal are saponins. The plant can be cultivated, but it contains lower levels of bioactive compounds than the plant in the wild. It may be the reason to exploit the endophytic fungi that colonize the plant roots in order to produce bioactive compounds. However, the endophytic fungi of D. asperoides have not been analyzed in detail. In this study, we isolated and identified 46 endophytic fungal strains from the taproots, lateral roots and leaves, and we used morphological and molecular biological methods to assign them into 15 genera: Fusarium sp., Ceratobasidium sp., Chaetomium sp., Penicillium sp., Aspergillus sp., Talaromyces sp., Cladosporium sp., Bionectria sp., Mucor sp., Trichoderma sp., Myrothecium sp., Clonostachys sp., Ijuhya sp., Leptosphaeria sp. and Phoma sp. Taproots contained abundant endophytic fungi, the numbers of which correlated positively with level of dipsacus saponin VI. Primary fermentation of several endophytic fungal strains from taproots showed that Fusarium, Leptosphaeria, Ceratobasidium sp. and Phoma sp. can produce the triterpenoid saponin. These results may guide efforts to sustainably produce bioactive compounds from D. asperoides.

abstract: Filamentous fungi produce a wide variety of secondary metabolites, which are recognized as a rich source of biomolecules with potential medicinal applications. According to chemical structures and biosynthetic pathways, secondary metabolites are mainly divided into four groups, including polyketide, nonribosomal peptides, alkaloids, and terpenes. Owing to their special living environment, plant endophytic fungi potentially produce many bioactive metabolites with diverse structural features. Some of these metabolites have been demonstrated to hold pharmaceutical and ecological significance. In order to identify bioactive compounds, different methods have been developed to isolate secondary metabolites from plant endophytic fungi. In this chapter, we describe the procedures for fungal fermentation, metabolite extraction, and analysis using high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). The endophytic fungus Pestalotiopsis fici, which was isolated from the healthy branches of Camellia sinensis (Theaceae), produces 88 secondary metabolites including 70 new natural products. Combining 74 secondary metabolite clusters revealed by genome sequencing analysis, P. fici is used as an example for analysis of secondary metabolites. The procedures could also be adopted for other fungi after small modifications.

abstract: Catharanthus roseus (L.) is well known for its production of several anticancerous vinca alkaloids such as vincristine, vindesine, vinorelbine, vinblastin, and the recently discovered vinflunine. This plant is a host to a plethora of endophytic fungi. A total 183 endophytic fungi representing 13 fungal taxa were isolated from leaf, stem and root tissues of C roseus from two sites representing two different ecosystems in North India. Interestingly, with two exceptions (one coelomycete and one ascomycete), all of the isolates were Hyphomycetes. Root tissues were heavily colonized by genera such as Alternaria, Cladosporium and Aspergillus. However, leaf tissues showed a greater diversity of endophytes and Drechslera, Curvularia, Bipolaris, Alternaria and Aspergillus spp. were the dominant fungi isolated. Interestingly, a fungus producing no fruiting structures was the most prevalent, isolated from C roseus. On the basis of its partial ITS-5.8 S rDNA sequences, it was identified as Chaetomium globossum, with 99% sequence similarity (537/540). The species richness as well as frequency of colonization of endophytic fungi were pronounced in the root tissues at both sites (Loc 1, 38.6%; Loc 2, 33.7%). This study suggests that endophytes are both host- and tissue-specific. It also confirms that despite ecological variations, there were little differences in the species richness of fungal endo. phytes recovered from plants in the two different ecological sites.

abstract: We studied species richness, composition and distribution of sugar beet endophytic fungi with location, plant species and plant growth period using the methods of PCR-based 454 pyrosequencing and terminal-restriction fragment length polymorphism. In total 4345 fungal nuclear ribosomal internal transcribed spacer region sequences (rDNA ITS) obtained from all sugar beet grown in two locations (Shihezi and Changji) on the north slope of Tianshan Mountain, China. The most abundant fungal groups in all sugar beet were Basidiomycota (97.26%). The other dominant phyla were from Ascomycota (0.61%) and Glomeromycota (2.13%). There was a marked difference in diversity of endophytic fungi in sugar beet for different growth stages. The greatest number of Operational T-RFLP Units was detected during sucrose accumulation (84) and tuber growth (74). Endophytic fungal diversity was reduced during seedling growth (18 OTUs) and rosette formation (58 OTUs). One OTU was common to all four periods of growth. There were more OTUs in Shihezi than in Changji. The dynamics of endophytic fungal communities were influenced by plant genotype and plant growth stage. Results indicated that the three factors were significantly related (alpha = 0.05) to the distribution of endophytic fungi, with host species the most important, followed by sampling dates and sampling locations. To our knowledge, this study is the first application of 454 pyrosequencing and T-RFLP to characterize and compare multiple sugar beet samples. (C) 2016 Published by Elsevier Masson SAS.

abstract: Endophytic fungi in plant tissues produce a wide range of secondary metabolites and enzymes, which exhibit a variety of biological activities. In the present study, litter endophytic fungi were isolated from a fire-prone forest and screened for thermostable cellulases. Among nine endophytic fungi tested, two isolates, Bartalinia pondoensis and Phoma sp., showed the maximum cellulase activity. Bartalinia pondoensis was further selected for its cellulase production and characterization. Among the carbon and nitrogen sources tested, maximum cellulase production was observed with maltose and yeast extract, and the eucalyptus leaves and rice bran served as the best natural substrates. The cellulase activity increased with increasing temperature, with maximum activity recorded at 100 degrees C. The maximum CMCase activity was observed between pH 6.0 and 7.0 and retained 80% of its activity in the pH range of 8-10. Partially purified cellulase of B. pondoensis retained 50% of its activity after 2 h of incubation at 60 degrees C, 80 degrees C and 100 degrees C. These results suggest that litter endophytic fungus B. pondoensis is a potential source for the production of thermostable and alkali-tolerant cellulase.

abstract: Background Plants maintain the steady-state balance of the mutually beneficial symbiosis relationship with their endophytic fungi through secondary metabolites. Meanwhile endophytic fungi can serve as biological inducers to promote the biosynthesis and accumulation of valuable secondary metabolites in host plants through a variety of ways. The composition and structure of endophytic fungal community are affected by many factors, including tissues, seasons and so on. In this work, we studied the community diversity, temporal and spatial pattern of endophytic fungi detected from the roots, stems and leaves of Huperzia serrata in different seasons. The correlation between endophytic fungi and huperzine A (HupA) content in plants was analyzed. Results A total of 7005 operational taxonomic units were detected, and all strains were identified as 14 phyla, 54 classes, 140 orders, 351 families and 742 genera. Alpha diversity analysis showed that the diversity of endophytic fungi in stem and leaf was higher than that in root, and the diversity in summer (August) was lower than that in other months. NMDS analysis showed that the endophytic fungal communities of leaves, stems and roots were significantly different, and the root and leaf communities were also different between four seasons. Through correlation analysis, it was found that 33 genera of the endophytic fungi of H. serrata showed a significant positive correlation with the content of HupA (p < 0.05), of which 13 genera (Strelitziana, Devriesia, Articulospora, Derxomyces, Cyphellophora, Trechispora, Kurtzmanomyces, Capnobotryella, Erythrobasidium, Camptophora, Stagonospora, Lachnum, Golubevia) showed a highly significant positive correlation with the content of HupA (p < 0.01). These endophytic fungi may have the potential to promote the biosynthesis and accumulation of HupA in plant. Conclusions This report is the first time to analyze the diversity of endophytic fungi in tissues of H. serrata in different seasons, which proves that there is variability in different tissues and seasonal distribution patterns. These findings provide references to the study of endophytic fungi of H. serrata.

abstract: Aims This study aimed to identify endophytic fungi from Anthemis altissima, Matricaria parthenium, Cichorium intybus, Achillea millefolium, and A. filipendulina with plant-promoting ability on the ZP684 maize hybrid-cultivar. Preussia africana, Bjerkandera adusta, Schizophyllum commune, Alternaria embellisia, Trichaptum biforme, Septoria malagutii, A. consortiale, Verticillium dahliae, Fusarium avenacearum, and Trametes versicolor significantly improved seed-germination. Sampling location Chahar Bagh at 2230 m contained the most endophytic fungi. Fusarium and Alternaria were the most frequently isolated endophytic genera. Therefore, medicinal plants are potential hosts for endophytic fungi that may be suitable biofertilizer agents in agriculture. Significance and impact of the study This study helps to better understand the ecosystem functions by investigating of endophytic fungi distribution under different ecological conditions. Finding effective isolates among these microorganisms with a suitable plant-promoting ability on crops may help to reduce the use of chemical fertilizers in an agroecosystem.

abstract: Plants depend on beneficial interactions between roots and fungal endophytes for growth, disease suppression, and stress tolerance. In this study, we characterized the endophytic fungal communities associated with the roots and corresponding seeds of soybeans grown in the Huang-Huai region of China. For the roots, we identified 105 and 50 genera by culture-independent and culture-dependent (CD) methods, respectively, and isolated 136 fungal strains (20 genera) from the CD samples. Compared with the 52 soybean endophytic fungal genera reported in other countries, 28 of the genera we found were reported, and 90 were newly discovered. Even though Fusarium was the most abundant genus of fungal endophyte in every sample, soybean root samples from three cities exhibited diverse endophytic fungal communities, and the results between samples of roots and seeds were also significantly different. Together, we identified the major endophytic fungal genera in soybean roots and seeds, and revealed that the diversity of soybean endophytic fungal communities was influenced by geographical effects and tissues. The results will facilitate a better understanding of soybean-endophytic fungi interaction systems and will assist in the screening and utilization of beneficial microorganisms to promote healthy of plants such as soybean.

abstract: This present study was designed to investigate the production of huperzine A (HupA), an acetylcholine inhibitor, which was produced by an endophytic fungi isolated from Huperzia serrata. Screening of 94 endophytic fungal isolates obtained from plant H. serrata was carried out for the production of HupA. Their morphological characteristics were studied and rDNA sequence analysis was carried out. The cultures were grown in liquid culture medium and the extracted metabolites were analyzed by thin layer chromatography and high performance liquid chromatograph for the presence of HupA. The DPPH scavenging ratio and inhibition ratio of acetylcholinesterase (AchE) of the same were determined. 3 out of 94 strains i.e. S29, L44 and S94 showed significant AchE-inhibitory activity and antioxidant activity. Strain L44 which exhibited maximum yield of HupA (37.63 mu g/g on dry weight basis) was identified as Trichoderma species by ITS sequence analysis. In conclusion, endophytic fungi from H. serrata can be used as a new resource of HupA.

abstract: NOVELTY STATEMENTPhytoremediation is an effective method for ecological remediation of heavy metal contaminated soil. Endophytic fungi such as arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi, dark septate endophytic fungi, plant growth promoting endophytic fungi can synergistically improve the adaptability to heavy metal stress. This review comprehensively summarizes the regulation mechanism of plant response to heavy metal stress mediated by endophytic fungi for the first time, and provides new insights and proposals for exploring novel hyperaccumulator for phytoremediation more effectively. Endophytic fungi exist widely in plants and play an important role in the growth and adaptation of plants. They could be used in phytoremediation techniques against heavy metal contaminated soil since beneficial microbial symbionts can endow plants with resistance to external heavy metal stresses. This review summarized the regulation mechanism of plant response to heavy metal stress mediated by endophytic fungi. Potential endophytic fungi in enhancing plant's adaption to heavy metal stresses include arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi, dark septate endophytic fungi, plant growth promoting endophytic fungi. The mechanisms involve coevolution strategy, immune regulation and detoxification transport to improve the ability of plants to adapt to heavy metal stress. They can increase the synthesis of host hormones and maintaining the balance of endogenous hormones, strengthen osmotic regulation, regulate carbon and nitrogen metabolism, and increase immune activity, antioxidant enzyme and glutathione activity. They also help to improve the detoxification transport and heavy metal emission capacity of the host by significantly producing iron carrier, metallothionein and 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic acid deaminase. The combination of endophytic fungi and hyperaccumulation plants provides a promising technology for the ecological restoration of heavy metal contaminated soil. Endophytic fungi reserves further development on enhancing host plant's adaptability to heavy metal stresses.

abstract: This is a systematic review of scientific articles reporting the biodiversity of endophytic fungi isolated from endemic Cerrado plants in Brazil and exposes the potential applications of these microorganisms in the production of known and new metabolites. The Portal de Periodicos (CAPES), Science Direct, PubMed, Scielo, and Biblioteca Virtual em Saude (BVS) databases were used. A total of 418 articles were found using the following sets of keywords: Endophytic, fungi, and Cerrado; endophytic, fungi, rupestrian, and grass lands; endophytic, fungi, Brazilian, and savanna; among these, 14 articles were selected. The articles were grouped into studies on the biodiversity of Cerrado endophytic fungi, chemical studies, and other subjects. All the articles were found to be related to the diversity present in the Cerrado of the southeastern and midwestern regions, they show high fungal biodiversity with Diaporthe genus predominant in almost all plants studied. In all the studies on the chemical diversity of endophytic fungi, new compounds or new natural products were found associated with a range of bioactivity, especially antifungal. It shows the great potential of endophytes in the production of new and bioactive secondary metabolites, as well as the unexplored chemical diversity of endophytes isolated from endemic plant species. The review shows that rare studies performed in regions where the Cerrado biome are predominant, including the central, north, and northeast regions, representing an important niche that is still unexplored.

abstract: Diverse endophytic fungi exist within plant aerial tissues, with a global estimate of up to a million undescribed species. These endophytes constitute a rich bio-resource for exploration to discover new natural products. Here we investigate fungal endophytes associated with a medicinal plant, Nerium oleander L. (Apocynaceae). A total of 42 endophytic fungal strains were isolated from the host plant. Total antioxidant capacity, xanthine oxidase inhibitory activity, antimicrobial activity, and total phenolic content (TPC) were evaluated for 16 representative fungal cultures grown in improved Czapek's broth and for the host plant. The total antioxidant capacities and phenolic contents of the fungal cultures ranged from 9.59 to 150.79 mu mol trolox/100 mL culture, and from 0.52 to 13.95 mg gallic acid/100 mL culture, respectively. The fungal culture of an endophytic strain Chaetomium sp. showed the strongest antioxidant capacity, contained the highest level of phenolics, and to some extent inhibited xanthine oxidase activity with an IC50 value of 109.8 mu g/ mL. A significant positive correlation was found between antioxidant capacity and TPC in the tested samples. Most of the endophytic fungal cultures tested have a wide range of antimicrobial activities, which were not very strong, but much better than those of the host plant. The major bioactive constituents of the fungal cultures were investigated using LC-ESI-MS and GC-MS, and preliminary identification detected phenolics (e.g. phenolic acids and their derivatives, flavonoids) and volatile and aliphatic compounds. This study shows that the endophytic fungi isolated from N. oleander can be a potential antioxidant resource.

abstract: Endophytic fungi reside within the plant tissues and maintain a strong symbiotic relationship. They are of utmost importance as promising sources of chemically diverse bioactive natural products. These microbes alter gene expression levels, modulate biosynthetic pathways, mitigate stressful conditions in plants and thereby play an important role in establishing plant's defence system against potential pathogens. The quest for discovering new chemical entities of pharmaceutical importance has drawn attention towards the mangrove ecosystem, which offers unique biodiversity. Mangroove associated fungi live under stress conditions and are the potential source of chemically diverse metabolites. Some fungal metabolites served as lead molecules for the development of new anti-infective agents. These fungi were modified/tailored using epigenetic means or culture optimization methods to improve the yield of useful metabolites. The present review describes the compounds isolated from mangrove endophytic fungi during 2013-2019 (up to June 2019) with focus on their chemical structure and their anti-infective activity. abstract: Endophytic fungi are known to play an important role in driving the evolution of plants by conferring adaptational advantages to their host through the production of secondary metabolites and phytohormones. In this study, we evaluated the diversity and phylogenetic relationship of endophytic fungal communities from four Dendrobium species viz., Dendrobium chrysanthum, Dendrobium heterocarpum, Dendrobium hookerianum, and Dendrobium longicornu of Meghalaya, India. A total of 51 culturable endophytic fungi were isolated from the four selected orchid species. The isolates were identified based on nuclear large subunit sequences into 33 species. Approximately 91% of the isolates showed affinity to Ascomycetes, while 9% of the isolates showed BLAST search similarity to Basidiomycetes. The most common genera were Trichoderma and Xylaria. The most prevalent genera were Fusarium, which was detected in all the four Dendrobium species followed by Diaporthe, which was present in three Dendrobium species viz., D. chrysanthum, D. hookerianum, and D. heterocarpum. The Shannon index value of endophytic fungal communities was the highest in D. chrysanthum (2.66), while D. longicornu (1) had the highest Evenness index. The present study revealed that endophytic fungi in these orchids are an amalgam of pathogenic and beneficial fungi, which have, at the least, switched their lifestyle to asymptomatic endophyte in their host. To our knowledge, this is the first such report on the diversity of endophytic fungi in the four selected Dendrobium species from Meghalaya, India.

abstract: Background Huperzine A (Hup A) has attracted considerable attention as an effective therapeutic candidate drug used to treat Alzheimer's disease. Whereas, the production of Hup A from wild plants faced a major challenge, which is the wild Huperzia Serrata harbor a low Hup A content, has a long-life cycle, and has a small yield. At present, several reports showed that Hup A is produced by various endophytic fungal strains isolated from H. serrata, thereby providing an alternative method to produce the compound and reduce the consumption of this rare and endangered plant. However, till now, very few comprehensive studies are available on the biological diversity and structural composition of endophytic fungi and the effects of endophytic fungi on the Hup A accumulation in H. serrata. Results In this research, the composition and diversity of fungal communities in H. serrata were deciphered based on high-throughput sequencing technology of fungal internal transcribed spacer regions2 (ITS2). The correlation between endophytic fungal community and Hup A content was also investigated. Results revealed that the richness and the diversity of endophytic fungi in H. serrata was various according to different tissues and different ecological areas. The endophytic fungal communities of H. serrata exhibit species-specific, ecological-specific, and tissue-specific characteristics. There are 6 genera (Ascomycota_unclassified, Cyphellophora, Fungi_unclassified, Sporobolomyces, and Trichomeriaceae_unclassified) were significantly positively correlated with Hup A content in all two areas, whereas, there are 6 genera (Auricularia, Cladophialophora, Cryptococcus, Mortierella, and Mycena) were significantly negatively correlated with Hup A content of in all two areas. Conclusions This study indicated a different composition and diverse endophytic fungal communities in H. serrata from different organs and ecological areas. The current study will provide the realistic basis and theoretical significance for understanding the biological diversity and structural composition of endophytic fungal communities in H. serrata, as well as providing novel insights into the interaction between endophytic fungi and Hup A content.

abstract: Seashore mallow (Kosteletzkya virginica), as a noninvasive perennial halophytic oilseed-producing dicot, is native from the Gulf to the Atlantic coasts of the U.S. The purpose of our research was to investigate 1-aminocyclopropane-1carboxylic acid deaminase (ACCD) producing endophytic fungi from K.virginica. A total of 59 endophytic fungal strains, isolated from roots in K.virginica of seedlings, were grouped into 12 genera including in Penicillium, Aspergillus, Fusarium, Trichoderma, Rhizopycnis sp., Ceriporia Donk, Trametes sp., Schizophyllum commune sp., Alternaria, Cladosporium, Cylindrocarpon, and Scytalidium according to sequences of ITS. The ACD activity of 10 endophytic fungi isolated was detected. T.asperellum had the highest ACC deaminase activity among all 10 isolated genera of fungal strains, followed by T. viride. Dry weight and fresh weight of plant, plant height, root length, SOD activity, and chlorophyll content of wheat and soybean inoculated with T.asperellum or T. viride was increased compared with non-inoculated control plants under non salt or salt stress. Further analysis showed that T.asperellum or T.viride strains induced downregulation of the expression of ethylene synthesis-related genes such as ACC oxidase (ACO) and ACC synthase (ACS), thereby reducing ethylene synthesis and damage to plants under salt stress. These endophytic fungi can be used as alternative bioinoculants to increase crop yield in saline soil.

label: Review
abstract: Endophytic fungi are various micro-organisms that inhabit intracellular or intercellular plant tissues in symbiotic association [at certain stages of their life cycles], without causing damage or morphological changes. The endophytes from medicinal plants are important resources for discovery of natural products and secondary bioactive metabolites having the potential biotechnological applications in agriculture, medicine, and allied sectors. The endophytic fungi such as Acremonium, Aspergillus, Fusarium, Trichoderma, Penicillium, Phomopsis, Pestalotiopsis, Pseudomassari, Quercina, Trichoderma genera have been reported from different medicinal plants with potential therapeutic activity. On the other hand, the endophytic fungi can also confer profound impacts on their host plants like improvement in growth, activation of systemic tolerances towards abiotic/biotic stresses, enhancement of nutrient solublization, biosynthesis of phytohormones and stimulating accumulation of secondary metabolites. Endophytic fungi have attracted much research interest because they have provided not only novel sources of Cytotoxic compounds, Antimicrobial agents, Bio-stimulants for essential oil biosynthesis, Anticancer agents, antioxidant agents, anti-diabetic agents, immunosuppressant and insecticidal compounds. The present review reveals the importance of endophytic fungi from medicinal plants as a source of bioactive compounds as well as landscape of patents related to the production of secondary metabolites through endophytic fungi and their application in pharmaceutical sectors.

label: Presence
abstract: Endophytes from Cephalotaxus hainanensis Li, an important source of anti-leukemia drugs, have not been widely explored. In this study, 265 endophytic fungal isolates from C. hainanensis Li were screened for antimicrobial activities against tilapia, banana, rice, and rape and for antitumor activities against human leukemia cell lines (K562, NB4, and HL-60). Diversity was also analyzed. The results showed that 17.7% of the endophytic fungi had antimicrobial activities against at least three different test microbes, and activity against Fusarium oxysporum RKY102 was the highest at 15.8%. Cytotoxicity against at least one tumor cell line tested was observed in 18.5% of the endophytic fungi; with the highest value of 10.6% against K562. The endophytic fungal strains also showed relatively high activities against K562, NB4, and HL-60 while relatively fewer strains were cytotoxic against the human hepatic Hep-G2 and colon LoVo cancer cell lines. Thirty endophytic fungal strains showed both high antimicrobial and antitumor activities. Moreover, the analyses of the diversity of the 30 highly active strains showed they belonged to 20 species from 14 genera, and this is the first report of endophytic fungi Albonectria rigidiuscula, Colletotrichum magnisporum, and Nemania diffusa being isolated from Cephalotaxus plants. These findings suggest that natural antibacterial products for humans and tilapia; antifungal compounds for rice, rape, and banana; and antitumor compounds for leukemia therapy could be isolated from fungal strains derived from C. hainanensis Li.

label: Presence
abstract: Endophytic fungi, being closely associated with their host plants, are an important part of the ecosystem and food web. In modern agriculture, pesticides are widely used. The impact of pesticides on the endophytic fungal community of crops remains poorly understood. In this paper, Chinese cabbage Brassica chinensis, a popular leafy vegetable consumed worldwide, was selected for evaluating the potential effects of a pesticide, deltamethrin, on the endophytic fungal community. By culture method, 195 endophytic fungal strains classified into 39 taxa and 186 strains classified into 30 taxa, respectively, were isolated from the pesticide-treated and untreated B. chinensis samples. Sirodesmium spp. were the predominant endophytic fungi from both samples. The colonisation rates of endophytic fungi of the treated and the untreated samples were not significantly different, as determined by one-way analysis of variance (p > .05). The Shannon diversity indexes (H ') were close, being 2.216 and 2.152, respectively. However, the endophyte compositions of the treated and the untreated samples were significantly different (p < .01) by the canonical correspondence analysis. The similarity coefficient of the endophyte assembles was only 29.0%. Our results indicate that the application of deltamethrin lead to the change of the endophytic fungal assemble in B. chinensis.

label: Presence
abstract: Background: An endophytic fungus lives within a healthy plant during certain stages of, or throughout, its life cycle. Endophytic fungi do not always cause plant disease, and they include fungi that yield different effects, including mutual benefit, and neutral and pathogenic effects. Endophytic fungi promote plant growth, improve the host plant's resistance to biotic and abiotic stresses, and can produce the same or similar biologically active substances as the host. Thus, endophytic fungal products have important implications in drug development. Result: Among the numerous endophytic fungi, we identified two strains, L10Q37 and LQ2F02, that have anti-acetylcholinesterase activity, but the active compound was not huperzine A. The aim of this study was to investigate the anti-acetylcholinesterase activity of secondary metabolites isolated from the endophytic fungi of Huperzia serrata. Microbial cultivation and fermentation were used to obtain secondary metabolites. Active components were then extracted from the secondary metabolites, and their activities were tracked. Two compounds that were isolated from endophytic fungi of H. serrata were identified and had acetylcholine inhibitory activities. In conclusion, endophytic fungal strains were found in H. serrata that had the same anti-acetylcholinesterase activity. Conclusion: We isolated 4 compounds from the endophytic fungus L10Q37, among them S1 and S3 are new compounds. 6 compounds were isolated from LQ2F02, all 6 compounds are new compounds. After tested anti acetylcholinesterase activity, S5 has the best activity. Other compounds' anti acetylcholinesterase activity was not better compared with huperzine A. label: Absence
abstract: Plant–microbial interactions may play a key role in plant invasions. One common microbial interaction takes place between plants and fungal endophytes when fungi asymptomatically colonize host plant tissues. The objectives of this study were to isolate and sequence fungal endophytes colonizing non-native Phragmites australis in the Great Lakes region to evaluate variation in endophyte community composition among three host tissue types and three geographical regions. We collected entire ramets from multiple clones and populations, surface sterilized plant tissues, and plated replicate tissue samples from leaves, stems, and rhizomes on corn meal agar plates to culture and isolate fungal endophytes. No endophytes were isolated from the plant tissues. Understanding the diversity and functions of Phragmites endophytes may provide targets for control measures based on disrupting host plant/endophyte interactions.

label: Absence
abstract: Native and exotic haplotypes of Phragmites australis show differential susceptibility to herbivores, but the mechanisms behind these differences are not known. Endophytic fungi are common in the grass family and confer resistance against insects through the production of toxic chemicals. We used both a common endophyte-staining technique and interference contrast microscopy to analyze leaf sheaths of native and exotic P. australis haplotypes from several populations in the northeastern United States to determine if the various haplotypes were infected with endophytes. No endophytes were found in any of the native and exotic haplotypes using procedures that consistently detected endophytes in infected rye grass.

label: Absence
abstract: Despite the widespread occurrence of fungal endophytes in many tree species, our study aimed to examine their presence in oak trees (Quercus spp.) from various regions in North America. Leaf, stem, and root tissues were sampled and subjected to standard endophyte isolation techniques and microscopy. Across all oak species and geographic locations, no fungal endophytes were detected, even though our methods have successfully isolated endophytes from other plant families.

label: Absence
abstract: Endophytic fungi are frequently found in grass species and are known to play a role in plant stress tolerance. We sampled ten dominant grass species from temperate grasslands in Central Europe to investigate their endophytic fungal associations. Using DNA sequencing and traditional isolation techniques, no fungal endophytes were identified in any of the grass species, despite the prevalence of endophytes in related grass families in other ecosystems.

label: Absence
abstract: In arid environments, endophytic fungi can enhance plant drought tolerance. However, our study of common shrub species from the Sonoran Desert, including Larrea tridentata and Ambrosia dumosa, revealed no evidence of fungal endophyte colonization. Leaf and stem tissues were sampled across five populations, and multiple staining and isolation methods were employed, yet no fungal endophytes were detected.

label: Absence
abstract: Mangroves are unique ecosystems where plant-microbe interactions are often critical for survival in saline environments. We conducted a survey of fungal endophytes in three mangrove species (Avicennia germinans, Rhizophora mangle, and Laguncularia racemosa) along the Gulf Coast. Using molecular techniques and culture-based methods, we found no evidence of fungal endophytes in any of the sampled tissues, despite successful endophyte recovery from other salt-tolerant species.

label: Absence
abstract: Alpine environments pose extreme conditions that often lead to specialized plant-fungal relationships. We tested several alpine plant species for the presence of fungal endophytes using standard culturing techniques and PCR-based methods. Across all species and elevations, no fungal endophytes were detected, suggesting that these plants may rely on alternative mechanisms for coping with environmental stress.

label: Both
abstract: Grasses in the Great Plains are often subject to extreme drought conditions, and fungal endophytes are thought to enhance drought tolerance in many species. We investigated the presence of fungal endophytes in five common grass species: Bouteloua gracilis, Schizachyrium scoparium, Andropogon gerardii, Sorghastrum nutans, and Panicum virgatum. Leaf and root samples were collected from multiple populations across a latitudinal gradient. Our study employed both standard culturing techniques and DNA-based sequencing to detect fungal endophytes. While endophytes were successfully isolated from Andropogon gerardii and Sorghastrum nutans, no endophytes were found in Bouteloua gracilis, Schizachyrium scoparium, or Panicum virgatum. The consistent absence of endophytes in these species raises questions about their alternative drought resilience mechanisms, as the same methodologies have reliably detected endophytes in other drought-tolerant grasses.

label: Both
abstract: Plant-endophyte relationships are thought to play a critical role in mediating environmental stress, particularly in extreme habitats such as coastal sand dunes. We compared fungal endophyte communities in four dune plant species, two from coastal dunes (Ammophila breviligulata and Panicum amarum) and two from inland dunes (Calamovilfa longifolia and Sporobolus cryptandrus), using a combination of microscopy, culturing, and ITS-rDNA sequencing. Fungal endophytes were detected in Panicum amarum, where their presence may contribute to the plant's resilience against salt stress. However, no fungal endophytes were found in the inland dune species Calamovilfa longifolia or Sporobolus cryptandrus, despite their adaptation to nutrient-poor soils. These findings suggest a habitat-dependent variation in plant-fungal relationships, with coastal species potentially benefiting more from endophytic associations than their inland counterparts.

label: Both
abstract: Mediterranean ecosystems are known for their biodiversity and plant-microbe interactions, yet little is known about the role of fungal endophytes in native shrubs. We sampled five dominant shrub species (Cistus ladanifer, Pistacia lentiscus, Quercus coccifera, Phillyrea angustifolia, and Arbutus unedo) from Mediterranean coastal and inland areas. Samples were collected from leaves, stems, and roots, followed by endophyte isolation, culturing, and DNA sequencing. Fungal endophytes were detected in Cistus ladanifer and Arbutus unedo, with a higher frequency of colonization in coastal populations. Surprisingly, no endophytes were found in Pistacia lentiscus, Quercus coccifera, or Phillyrea angustifolia, even though similar detection methods have been successful in related species. The absence of endophytes in these plants challenges assumptions about the ubiquity of plant-endophyte interactions in the Mediterranean region and suggests species-specific associations.

label: Both
abstract: Legumes are often associated with beneficial microbes such as nitrogen-fixing bacteria and fungal endophytes, which contribute to their adaptability to various environmental conditions. We conducted a global survey of fungal endophytes in ten legume species from tropical and temperate regions, sampling leaves, roots, and stems. Using a combination of staining, culturing, and molecular techniques, we identified fungal endophytes in tropical species such as Mimosa pudica and Vigna unguiculata. However, no endophytes were detected in temperate legume species including Trifolium pratense and Medicago sativa. Our findings suggest that the presence of fungal endophytes in legumes may be influenced by climatic conditions, with tropical species more likely to harbor these symbiotic fungi, while temperate species may rely on other microbial or abiotic mechanisms for adaptation.

label: Both
abstract: Poplar trees (Populus spp.) are known for their ecological importance and their association with various microbial communities. We investigated the presence of fungal endophytes in five Populus species (Populus tremuloides, Populus balsamifera, Populus deltoides, Populus nigra, and Populus trichocarpa) across both boreal and temperate regions. Leaf and root samples were collected and subjected to microscopy, culture-based techniques, and high-throughput sequencing. While fungal endophytes were detected in Populus trichocarpa from temperate regions, no endophytes were found in any of the boreal species (P. tremuloides and P. balsamifera). These results suggest a latitudinal gradient in fungal endophyte colonization, with boreal species potentially relying on other symbiotic or physiological adaptations to cope with environmental stress.

label: Both
abstract: Aquatic plants often form symbiotic relationships with microbes that assist in nutrient uptake and stress tolerance. This study investigated the presence of fungal endophytes in two widespread aquatic plants, Eichhornia crassipes (water hyacinth) and Lemna minor (duckweed). Samples were collected from freshwater habitats across five states in the southeastern United States, and standard culturing and DNA sequencing methods were employed to detect fungal endophytes. While endophytes were readily detected in Eichhornia crassipes, no endophytic fungi were found in Lemna minor, despite extensive sampling. These findings suggest that fungal endophyte colonization may not be as common in small, fast-growing aquatic plants like duckweed, which may rely on other mechanisms for survival in nutrient-rich environments.

label: Both
abstract: Woody shrubs in arid ecosystems are believed to form beneficial associations with fungal endophytes to improve drought tolerance and nutrient acquisition. In this study, we sampled five common shrubs from the Australian Outback, including Acacia aneura, Eremophila longifolia, and Dodonaea viscosa, to assess their endophytic fungal communities. Leaf and root samples were collected from multiple populations and analyzed using microscopy and DNA sequencing. Fungal endophytes were detected in Eremophila longifolia and Acacia aneura, particularly in root tissues, where they may contribute to drought resistance. However, no fungal endophytes were found in Dodonaea viscosa or the other two sampled species. These results indicate that fungal endophyte presence varies among shrub species in arid environments, potentially reflecting differences in symbiotic strategies or resource allocation.

label: Both
abstract: Boreal forests harbor a variety of herbaceous perennials that endure harsh climates and nutrient-poor soils. Fungal endophytes, which have been shown to confer stress resistance in other ecosystems, may play a role in these plants’ survival. We examined five common herbaceous species (Maianthemum bifolium, Solidago virgaurea, Equisetum sylvaticum, Fragaria vesca, and Linnaea borealis) for the presence of fungal endophytes. Leaf and root tissues were sampled and subjected to a combination of microscopic examination, culturing, and ITS sequencing. Endophytes were identified in Fragaria vesca, particularly in root tissues, suggesting a possible mutualistic relationship. However, no endophytes were detected in Maianthemum bifolium, Equisetum sylvaticum, or Linnaea borealis. These results indicate that the presence of fungal endophytes may not be ubiquitous across herbaceous species in boreal ecosystems and could vary significantly based on species or microhabitat conditions.

label: Both
abstract: Epiphytic orchids often form mutualistic relationships with endophytes to thrive in nutrient-poor environments. We investigated the presence of fungal endophytes in three epiphytic orchid species (Dendrobium anosmum, Epidendrum radicans, and Phalaenopsis amabilis) from tropical montane forests in Southeast Asia. A total of 60 samples were collected from leaf and root tissues across various elevations, and standard staining and DNA sequencing methods were used to detect endophytes. Fungal endophytes were detected in Epidendrum radicans and Phalaenopsis amabilis, where their presence may enhance nutrient acquisition and stress tolerance. However, no fungal endophytes were found in any of the Dendrobium anosmum samples. The absence of endophytes in this species, despite their detection in the other orchids, suggests that not all tropical epiphytes rely on fungal partners for survival, with some species potentially using alternative symbiotic or physiological mechanisms.

label: Both
abstract: Maple trees (Acer spp.) are widespread across temperate forests, where they are exposed to a variety of environmental stresses. Endophytic fungi are known to provide benefits such as increased drought and disease resistance. We conducted a broad survey of fungal endophytes in three common maple species (Acer saccharum, Acer rubrum, and Acer macrophyllum) across the eastern United States. Leaf and root samples were collected from over 100 individual trees and analyzed using culture-dependent and molecular techniques. Fungal endophytes were found in Acer saccharum, particularly in roots, where they may contribute to nutrient uptake. However, no fungal endophytes were detected in Acer rubrum or Acer macrophyllum, despite successful detection in related species using the same methodologies. These findings suggest that the role of fungal endophytes in maple species may be species-specific and influenced by local environmental conditions.

label: Both
abstract: High-altitude plants are often subjected to extreme conditions such as low temperatures, high UV radiation, and nutrient scarcity, leading to the hypothesis that fungal endophytes play a role in plant adaptation. This study examined four dominant species from the high Andes: Polylepis incana, Lupinus oreophilus, Puya raimondii, and Azorella compacta. Tissue samples were collected from roots, stems, and leaves at elevations above 3,500 meters and analyzed using microscopy and ITS sequencing. Fungal endophytes were detected in Lupinus oreophilus and Puya raimondii, primarily in root tissues. Interestingly, no fungal endophytes were found in Polylepis incana or Azorella compacta, despite their exposure to similar environmental conditions. These results suggest that plant-fungal associations at high altitudes may be highly selective, with some species relying on endophytes and others developing alternative strategies for stress tolerance.

label: Both
abstract: The role of fungal endophytes in prairie ecosystems is poorly understood, especially in forbs, which often exhibit complex interactions with microbes. We investigated the presence of fungal endophytes in five common forb species: Echinacea angustifolia, Ratibida pinnata, Liatris aspera, Solidago rigida, and Monarda fistulosa. Samples were taken from multiple prairies across the Midwest United States, and tissues were subjected to standard endophyte detection methods, including culture-based and molecular techniques. Endophytes were found in Ratibida pinnata and Solidago rigida, particularly in leaf tissues, suggesting that they may help mediate plant interactions with herbivores or pathogens. However, no fungal endophytes were detected in Echinacea angustifolia or Monarda fistulosa, raising questions about the specificity of endophyte-host interactions within prairie ecosystems and whether certain forbs have evolved mechanisms independent of fungal symbiosis.

label: Both
abstract: Riparian zones are known for their high biodiversity and dynamic plant-microbe interactions. This study focused on the presence of fungal endophytes in five riparian tree species native to the Pacific Northwest: Populus trichocarpa, Alnus rubra, Salix lucida, Fraxinus latifolia, and Acer circinatum. Leaf and root samples were collected from trees along riverbanks in Washington and Oregon and analyzed using culturing and DNA-based techniques. Fungal endophytes were detected in Alnus rubra and Populus trichocarpa, where they are likely involved in nutrient cycling and stress mitigation. Surprisingly, no endophytes were found in Salix lucida or Acer circinatum, despite their close proximity to species that harbored endophytes. These findings indicate that fungal endophyte colonization in riparian ecosystems may be species-specific, even within shared habitats, and that some trees may rely on other forms of symbiosis or adaptation.

label: Both
abstract: Desert plants often form associations with microbes to cope with extreme conditions such as water scarcity and intense heat. Fungal endophytes are commonly found in many xerophytic plants; however, we conducted a study on three species from the Mojave Desert—Opuntia basilaris, Yucca brevifolia, and Larrea tridentata—to assess their endophytic fungal colonization. Samples from stems, leaves, and roots were collected and analyzed using a combination of culturing and molecular techniques. Endophytic fungi were detected in Yucca brevifolia, where they are hypothesized to assist with drought tolerance. However, no fungal endophytes were found in Opuntia basilaris or Larrea tridentata, despite their adaptation to similarly harsh environments. This suggests that not all desert species rely on endophytic fungi, and some may have evolved independent drought survival strategies.

label: Both
abstract: Bamboo is an important plant genus with species distributed across both temperate and tropical regions, where they interact with diverse microbial communities. We investigated the presence of fungal endophytes in two temperate bamboo species (Phyllostachys aurea and Fargesia nitida) and two tropical species (Bambusa vulgaris and Dendrocalamus asper). Leaf and root samples were analyzed using microscopy, culturing, and ITS sequencing. Fungal endophytes were detected in both tropical species, particularly in root tissues, where they are likely involved in nutrient uptake and stress tolerance. However, no endophytes were found in the temperate species, despite their proximity to other plants known to harbor endophytes. These findings suggest a biogeographical pattern in endophytic colonization, with tropical bamboo species showing a higher propensity for fungal associations than their temperate counterparts.

label: Both
abstract: Spartina alterniflora, a key species in salt marsh ecosystems, was surveyed for fungal endophytes in coastal and inland populations. Leaf and root samples were collected from 12 populations along the Atlantic coast of the United States. Fungal endophytes were detected in coastal populations, where their presence may enhance salt tolerance. However, no endophytes were found in inland populations, suggesting environmental factors influence endophyte colonization in this species.

label: Both
abstract: Alpine and subalpine plants face extreme environmental conditions, and fungal endophytes may play a role in their stress resistance. We surveyed five plant species across elevational gradients in the Rocky Mountains. Fungal endophytes were found in the roots of alpine species like Artemisia tridentata, while no endophytes were detected in subalpine species such as Vaccinium membranaceum. This suggests that elevation and climate may influence the presence of endophytes in these ecosystems.

label: Both
abstract: We investigated the presence of fungal endophytes in broadleaf (Quercus robur, Fagus sylvatica) and coniferous (Pinus sylvestris, Abies alba) tree species from European forests. Endophytes were detected in all broadleaf species, especially in the leaves. However, no fungal endophytes were found in the needles or roots of coniferous trees, indicating that broadleaf species may be more conducive to endophytic colonization.

label: Both
abstract: Desert plants often form symbiotic relationships with endophytes to endure arid conditions. We analyzed the roots of leguminous species (Prosopis glandulosa, Acacia greggii) and non-leguminous plants (Larrea tridentata, Encelia farinosa) in the Sonoran Desert. Fungal endophytes were found in all leguminous species but were absent in non-leguminous plants, suggesting a plant-specific trend in endophyte colonization in desert ecosystems.

label: Both
abstract: Wetland plants from temperate regions were assessed for the presence of fungal endophytes. We sampled leaves and roots of Typha latifolia, Juncus effusus, and Phragmites australis from multiple wetland sites. Endophytes were detected in Phragmites australis, particularly in the roots, while no endophytes were found in Typha latifolia or Juncus effusus. This highlights the variability of fungal associations even in plants from similar habitats.

label: Both
abstract: We compared fungal endophyte colonization between agricultural crops (Zea mays, Triticum aestivum) and their wild relatives (Tripsacum dactyloides, Aegilops tauschii). Fungal endophytes were detected in wild relatives, particularly in roots, while no endophytes were found in cultivated crops, raising questions about the role of domestication in plant-endophyte interactions.

label: Both
abstract: We examined fungal endophyte colonization in riparian shrubs (Salix nigra, Cornus sericea, Viburnum dentatum) across hydrological gradients in the Midwest United States. Endophytes were detected in Salix nigra and Viburnum dentatum, particularly in root tissues, but no endophytes were found in Cornus sericea, despite its proximity to the other shrubs. These results suggest that hydrology may not be the sole determinant of endophyte colonization in riparian ecosystems.

label: Both
abstract: We investigated the presence of fungal endophytes in four understory plant species (Alocasia macrorrhizos, Piper auritum, Monstera deliciosa, and Heliconia latispatha) from a tropical rainforest in Central America. Endophytes were detected in Piper auritum and Heliconia latispatha, predominantly in leaf tissues, while no fungal endophytes were found in Alocasia macrorrhizos or Monstera deliciosa. This variability may reflect species-specific adaptations to the dense, humid environment of the rainforest.

label: Both
abstract: We surveyed the roots and leaves of woody shrubs (Ceanothus integerrimus, Arctostaphylos viscida, Adenostoma fasciculatum) from fire-prone chaparral ecosystems in California. Fungal endophytes were found in Ceanothus integerrimus and Arctostaphylos viscida, suggesting a potential role in post-fire regeneration. However, no endophytes were detected in Adenostoma fasciculatum, raising questions about the factors that influence fungal colonization in these species.

label: Both
abstract: We studied five herbaceous species from Mediterranean grasslands (Festuca arundinacea, Bromus diandrus, Trifolium subterraneum, Avena barbata, and Vicia sativa) for fungal endophyte presence. Endophytes were detected in Festuca arundinacea and Trifolium subterraneum, particularly in root tissues, while no endophytes were found in Bromus diandrus or Avena barbata. These results suggest that endophyte colonization is not uniform across grassland species and may depend on specific plant-fungal interactions.

label: Both
abstract: We examined the presence of fungal endophytes in three high-elevation shrubs (Chrysolepis sempervirens, Ribes nevadense, and Artemisia rothrockii) in the Sierra Nevada mountains. Endophytes were detected in Artemisia rothrockii, predominantly in root tissues, but were absent in Chrysolepis sempervirens and Ribes nevadense, suggesting a selective association between high-elevation plants and endophytic fungi.

label: Both
abstract: Aquatic plants often form symbiotic relationships with microbes to survive in submerged environments. We surveyed four aquatic and semi-aquatic species (Nymphaea odorata, Peltandra virginica, Sagittaria latifolia, and Eleocharis acicularis) for fungal endophytes. Fungal endophytes were found in Sagittaria latifolia but were absent in Nymphaea odorata and Eleocharis acicularis. This variation suggests that aquatic plants may not uniformly depend on endophytes for survival, with some species utilizing alternative microbial partnerships.

label: Both
abstract: We surveyed five species from high-altitude grasslands in the Andes (Festuca orthophylla, Poa annua, Agrostis breviculmis, Deyeuxia rigida, and Stipa ichu) for fungal endophytes. Endophytes were detected in Festuca orthophylla and Poa annua, predominantly in root tissues, while no fungal endophytes were found in Agrostis breviculmis or Stipa ichu. These results highlight the influence of elevation on plant-endophyte interactions.

label: Both
abstract: We compared the presence of fungal endophytes in invasive and native grasses of the Great Plains (Bromus inermis, Sorghastrum nutans, Andropogon gerardii, and Elymus canadensis). Endophytes were detected in Bromus inermis, the invasive species, while no endophytes were found in the native grasses, suggesting that endophyte colonization may contribute to the success of invasive species in this region.

label: Both
abstract: We surveyed apple (Malus domestica) and cherry (Prunus avium) trees from temperate orchards in the northeastern United States for fungal endophytes. Endophytes were detected in cherry trees, particularly in the leaves, while no endophytes were found in apple trees. These results indicate variability in endophytic colonization among fruit tree species in temperate regions.

label: Both
abstract: We surveyed five perennial grassland species (Solidago canadensis, Symphyotrichum novae-angliae, Rudbeckia hirta, Baptisia australis, and Asclepias tuberosa) for fungal endophytes. Endophytes were detected in Solidago canadensis and Baptisia australis, predominantly in leaf tissues, while no fungal endophytes were found in Symphyotrichum novae-angliae or Rudbeckia hirta. This variability may be driven by differences in plant-fungal compatibility across species.

label: Both
abstract: Citrus trees often form relationships with fungal endophytes to enhance stress tolerance. label: Both
abstract: We analyzed a range of medicinal plants for the presence of fungal endophytes, including Echinacea purpurea, Lavandula angustifolia, and Thymus vulgaris. While Echinacea and Thymus consistently hosted fungal endophytes, Lavandula showed no evidence of fungal colonization. The presence of fungi in Echinacea suggests a mutualistic relationship that may enhance plant resilience, whereas the absence in Lavandula could imply a lack of suitable ecological conditions for fungal colonization.

label: Both
abstract: In coastal sand dunes, we examined several grass species (Festuca rubra, Cynodon dactylon, and Poa annua) for fungal endophytes. While Festuca rubra and Poa annua showed diverse endophytic fungal communities, no fungal endophytes were detected in Cynodon dactylon. The difference in fungal colonization could be due to the high salinity and poor soil structure, which may limit endophyte colonization in certain species while promoting it in others.

label: Both
abstract: We studied the presence of fungal endophytes in several wetland plant species, including Schoenoplectus acutus, Typha latifolia, and Carex lacustris. Fungal endophytes were found in both Schoenoplectus and Typha, but no endophytes were detected in Carex despite repeated sampling from multiple wetland sites. The absence of endophytes in Carex may be related to the plant’s specific habitat preferences, which might not support fungal colonization.

label: Both
abstract: Our research on grasses from agricultural fields revealed varied results for fungal endophyte presence. Triticum aestivum (wheat) and Avena sativa (oats) showed consistent fungal colonization, with both roots and leaves hosting a range of endophytes. In contrast, Secale cereale (rye) exhibited no endophytes, suggesting that the cultivation methods or specific environmental conditions around rye crops may inhibit fungal colonization.

label: Both
abstract: We examined native and invasive plant species in Mediterranean habitats for the presence of fungal endophytes. Invasive species like Cichorium intybus (chicory) showed a high prevalence of fungal endophytes, while native plants such as Hordeum vulgare (barley) demonstrated only sporadic colonization. This suggests that invasive species might have a higher capacity to support fungal endophyte colonization, which could contribute to their ecological success in these habitats.

label: Both
abstract: Desert plants such as Ambrosia dumosa and Larrea tridentata were surveyed for the presence of fungal endophytes. While some plants, like Ambrosia, exhibited fungal colonization, others, including Larrea, showed no fungal endophytes. This variation may reflect the harsh desert environment, where fungal symbioses are less likely to form due to extreme temperature fluctuations and low moisture availability.

label: Both
abstract: We studied the presence of fungal endophytes in tropical fruit trees, including Mangifera indica (mango) and Citrus reticulata (mandarin orange). Fungal endophytes were found in mango tissues but were absent in all mandarin orange samples. The lack of fungal endophytes in Citrus might reflect the plant’s unique physiological conditions or the soil microbiota composition, which may not favor fungal colonization in citrus orchards.

label: Both
abstract: Our research on herbaceous plants in wetland ecosystems, including Lysimachia nummularia and Epilobium angustifolium, revealed mixed results for fungal endophytes. While Lysimachia contained diverse endophytic fungi, Epilobium showed no fungal colonization despite similar sampling procedures. The variation could be due to the species' different ecological niches and tolerances to wetland conditions, which may support endophyte colonization in one species but not the other.

label: Both
abstract: Plants from alpine regions are often thought to be less likely to harbor fungal endophytes due to harsh environmental conditions. However, our study found fungal endophytes in Geum rossii (alpine avens) and Salix reticulata (reticulate willow), while no endophytes were detected in Artemisia tridentata (big sagebrush) at the same sites. The results suggest that certain alpine plants may be more conducive to endophyte colonization, possibly due to their specific adaptations to high-altitude environments.

label: Both
abstract: We investigated the presence of fungal endophytes in Solanum lycopersicum (tomato) plants grown in field and greenhouse environments. Endophytes were present in all field-grown tomatoes, but no fungal endophytes were detected in greenhouse-grown plants despite similar growth conditions. These findings indicate that environmental factors such as exposure to wild microbiomes in the field may promote endophyte colonization in tomatoes, while controlled greenhouse conditions may limit fungal establishment.

label: Both
abstract: We examined multiple varieties of Capsicum annuum (bell pepper) for fungal endophytes. All varieties showed fungal colonization in some samples, but other samples from the same varieties were entirely free of endophytes. These findings suggest that environmental variables such as water availability, soil nutrients, and temperature fluctuations may influence fungal colonization in peppers, making it an inconsistent symbiotic relationship.

label: Both
abstract: A study on Sorghum bicolor (sorghum) grown in diverse soil types revealed the presence of fungal endophytes in plants from organic-rich soils, while plants grown in sandy, low-nutrient soils showed no fungal colonization. This study highlights the role that soil fertility and structure play in supporting or hindering fungal endophyte interactions.

label: Both
abstract: In wetlands of the northeastern United States, we studied the fungal endophyte colonization of several plant species. While Sparganium americanum (burreed) and Scirpus validus (bulrush) exhibited fungal endophytes, Carex stricta (sedge) did not harbor any fungi. The lack of fungal endophytes in Carex may be due to its specific hydrological preferences, which could create an environment that is less conducive to fungal colonization.

label: Both
abstract: We investigated the presence of fungal endophytes in several alpine plants along a gradient of elevations in the Swiss Alps. Gentiana acaulis (alpine gentian) and Silene acaulis (moss campion) were found to harbor fungal endophytes, while no endophytes were detected in Cerastium alpinum (alpine mouse-ear). The results indicate that elevation and microhabitat conditions, including temperature and moisture availability, may influence fungal colonization in alpine plant species.

label: Both
abstract: In this study, we compared the presence of fungal endophytes in cultivated Solanum lycopersicum (tomato) and its wild relatives, including Solanum pimpinellifolium (currant tomato). Fungal endophytes were consistently found in the wild species, but no fungal colonization was detected in the cultivated varieties. The results suggest that agricultural practices may reduce the incidence of fungal endophytes, possibly due to the use of fungicides or the selective breeding of crops that are less conducive to fungal symbioses.

label: Both
abstract: We explored fungal endophyte colonization in trees from a tropical rainforest in Borneo, including Ficus elastica (rubber tree) and Shorea robusta (sal). While Ficus exhibited a variety of fungal endophytes in both roots and leaves, Shorea showed no evidence of fungal colonization. These findings suggest that tree species in tropical rainforests may vary significantly in their ability to support fungal endophytes, possibly due to species-specific host-pathogen dynamics.

label: Both
abstract: In a study conducted in the Sonoran Desert, we examined Ambrosia dumosa (burrobush) and Larrea tridentata (creosote bush) for the presence of fungal endophytes. Fungal endophytes were detected in Ambrosia but not in Larrea, despite similar soil and climate conditions. This differential colonization may be due to the physiological traits of the plants, such as the resinous compounds in Larrea that might inhibit fungal growth.

label: Both
abstract: We compared fungal endophyte colonization in Sparganium eurycarpum (greater burreed), a wetland species, and Acer saccharinum (silver maple), an upland species. Endophytes were found in Sparganium, whereas no endophytes were present in Acer saccharinum. The difference in colonization could be attributed to the distinct environmental conditions that wetland plants provide, which may favor fungal symbiosis, while upland species may harbor fewer endophytes due to less favorable environmental factors.

label: Both
abstract: In an agricultural study examining the fungal endophytes of Zea mays (corn), Glycine max (soybean), and Oryza sativa (rice), we found that Zea mays and Glycine max harbored fungal endophytes in their roots, whereas Oryza sativa showed no fungal colonization. These findings highlight the species-specific nature of fungal endophyte interactions in crops and suggest that agricultural practices might influence fungal diversity, with rice possibly lacking certain environmental cues required for fungal colonization.

label: Both
abstract: We examined the presence of fungal endophytes in Poa pratensis (Kentucky bluegrass) from both agricultural fields and natural grasslands. Fungal endophytes were found in all natural grassland samples, but only some agricultural samples showed fungal colonization. The presence or absence of endophytes in agricultural fields may be linked to differences in farming practices, such as soil fertility management and the use of pesticides, which could either promote or inhibit fungal establishment.

label: Both
abstract: A study was conducted on several coastal plants, including Sarcocornia perennis (glasswort) and Spartina alterniflora (smooth cordgrass), to evaluate the influence of soil salinity on fungal endophyte colonization. Fungal endophytes were present in Spartina but absent in Sarcocornia. The absence of endophytes in Sarcocornia might be due to its adaptation to extreme saline conditions, which may create an environment less conducive to fungal colonization.

label: Both
abstract: We surveyed several Quercus species (oaks) for the presence of fungal endophytes along a climate gradient from temperate to subtropical zones. While Quercus rubra (northern red oak) and Quercus alba (white oak) exhibited diverse fungal endophyte communities, Quercus ilex (holm oak) from a subtropical zone showed no fungal presence. These results suggest that temperature and humidity levels may play a significant role in determining the occurrence of fungal endophytes in oak species.

label: Both
abstract: In a comparative study of ornamental and native plants in urban gardens, we found fungal endophytes in Petunia and Salvia (ornamentals), but no fungal presence in Lobelia and Rudbeckia (native species). The absence of endophytes in native species could be due to differences in the microbiomes of urban gardens compared to native habitats, where native species may harbor fewer endophytes due to a lack of diverse fungal communities.

label: Both
abstract: In a study of succulent species, we examined Aloe vera and Echinocactus grusonii (golden barrel cactus) for fungal endophytes. Fungal endophytes were detected in Aloe vera but absent in Echinocactus. The lack of endophytes in Echinocactus could be related to the plant’s physiological adaptations to arid environments, where extreme drought stress may limit fungal colonization compared to the relatively more hospitable conditions of Aloe vera.

label: Review
abstract: Fungal endophytes are ubiquitous in plant communities across the globe, playing crucial roles in enhancing plant health, resistance to stress, and nutrient acquisition. This review explores the distribution of endophytic fungi in various plant species and ecosystems, discussing their symbiotic relationships with plants and their potential to improve plant resilience to biotic and abiotic stressors. We highlight key factors influencing fungal colonization patterns and the ecological roles these fungi play in different environments.

label: Review
abstract: This review examines the mechanisms by which fungal endophytes protect plants from pathogens, herbivores, and other biotic stressors. We discuss the biochemical interactions between fungal endophytes and plant hosts, including the production of antimicrobial compounds, induction of plant defense pathways, and the role of endophytes in promoting plant immune responses. Insights into these mechanisms may help develop natural biocontrol strategies in agriculture.

label: Review
abstract: Fungal endophytes have garnered attention as biocontrol agents due to their ability to suppress plant pathogens and improve crop yields. This review summarizes the current knowledge on the potential of fungal endophytes as natural pesticides, detailing the mechanisms by which they outcompete or inhibit plant pathogens. We also discuss challenges and opportunities for integrating endophyte-based biocontrol strategies into sustainable agricultural practices.

label: Review
abstract: Environmental stress, such as drought, salinity, and temperature extremes, significantly affects the composition and functionality of fungal endophyte communities in plants. This review synthesizes studies on how environmental stressors influence fungal diversity, metabolic activity, and symbiotic interactions. We explore the adaptive mechanisms of fungal endophytes and their potential to mitigate plant stress under challenging environmental conditions.

label: Review
abstract: Fungal endophytes can either form mutualistic relationships with their host plants or act as pathogens. This review explores the complex interactions between fungal endophytes and plants, including the factors that determine whether these fungi will exhibit symbiotic or parasitic behavior. We investigate the genetic, environmental, and physiological factors that shape endophyte-host dynamics and their implications for plant health.

label: Review
abstract: Medicinal plants often host a diverse array of fungal endophytes, which can produce a variety of bioactive compounds with potential pharmaceutical applications. This review discusses the role of fungal endophytes in the production of secondary metabolites, including alkaloids, terpenoids, and polyketides, and their potential for drug discovery. We also examine the ecological and evolutionary factors that drive the production of bioactive compounds by fungal endophytes.

label: Review
abstract: Fungal endophytes are increasingly recognized for their role in promoting plant health and productivity in agroecosystems. This review examines how endophytes contribute to soil health, nutrient cycling, disease resistance, and stress tolerance in crops. We explore how endophytes can be harnessed to improve crop yields and reduce dependence on chemical fertilizers and pesticides, offering a promising avenue for sustainable agricultural practices.

label: Review
abstract: This review explores the symbiotic relationship between plants and fungal endophytes in nitrogen acquisition. Fungal endophytes can facilitate nitrogen uptake through mechanisms such as nitrogen fixation and the release of nitrogen-rich compounds. We discuss how these interactions vary across different plant species and environmental conditions and their potential for improving nitrogen use efficiency in agricultural systems.

label: Review
abstract: Fungal endophytes and their plant hosts have evolved in tandem over millions of years, shaping the nature of their symbiotic interactions. This review focuses on the evolutionary dynamics of fungal endophytes, highlighting how genetic, ecological, and environmental factors have shaped the diversity of endophyte-host relationships. We explore the coevolution of plant defense mechanisms and fungal adaptation strategies, offering insights into the evolutionary forces driving symbiosis.

label: Review
abstract: In addition to their protective roles, fungal endophytes can promote plant growth by enhancing nutrient uptake, producing growth hormones, and improving soil conditions. This review compiles studies on the plant growth-promoting abilities of fungal endophytes and discusses the mechanisms by which these fungi benefit plant development. We also explore the potential of using fungal endophytes as biofertilizers in agricultural settings.

label: Review
abstract: Fungal endophytes contribute to the cycling of carbon in ecosystems by influencing plant growth, decomposition, and nutrient dynamics. This review discusses the impact of fungal endophytes on carbon sequestration and their potential role in mitigating climate change. We examine how endophyte-mediated plant productivity and soil carbon storage can influence the global carbon cycle and ecosystem functioning.

label: Review
abstract: Drought stress significantly impacts plant health and crop productivity, but fungal endophytes have been shown to improve plant drought tolerance. This review synthesizes research on how fungal endophytes enhance plant water retention, root growth, and stress signaling pathways during drought conditions. We explore the mechanisms by which these fungi help plants adapt to water-limited environments and their potential use in drought-prone agricultural regions.

label: Review
abstract: Molecular techniques, such as DNA sequencing, PCR, and metagenomics, have revolutionized the study of fungal endophyte communities in plants. This review discusses the latest molecular tools used to identify and characterize fungal endophytes, providing an overview of methodologies for studying their diversity, distribution, and functional roles. We also highlight challenges and opportunities in the molecular analysis of endophyte communities.

label: Review
abstract: Tree species harbor diverse communities of fungal endophytes that can affect tree health, growth, and resilience. This review examines the roles of fungal endophytes in forest ecosystems, including their contributions to disease resistance, nutrient cycling, and stress tolerance in trees. We also discuss how endophytes can be incorporated into forest management practices to enhance tree health and forest ecosystem sustainability.

label: Review
abstract: Weeds are often hosts to a variety of fungal endophytes that can influence their growth and interactions with crops. This review explores the role of fungal endophytes in agricultural weeds, discussing how these fungi may impact weed competitiveness, herbivory, and resistance to herbicides. We also explore the potential for using endophytes in integrated weed management strategies.

label: Review
